title: Modified Hoehn and Yahr Scale for Parkinson's Disease
description: Grades severity of symptoms in Parkinson's disease with intermediate stages for better disease progression tracking

parameters.name: clinical_stage
parameters.description: Clinical stage based on motor symptoms and functional disability

result.name: hoehn_yahr_stage
result.description: Modified Hoehn and Yahr stage indicating Parkinson's disease severity

ranges.interpretation: Unilateral involvement only, usually with minimal or no functional disability.
Unilateral and axial involvement (neck, trunk) without impairment of balance.

ranges.description: Bilateral involvement without impairment of balance
ranges.interpretation: Bilateral involvement without impairment of balance; minimal disability.

ranges.description: Mild bilateral disease with recovery on pull test
ranges.interpretation: Mild bilateral disease with recovery on pull test; physically independent.

ranges.description: Bilateral disease; mild to moderate disability
ranges.interpretation: Bilateral disease; mild to moderate disability with impaired postural reflexes; physically independent.

ranges.description: Severe disability; still able to walk or stand unassisted
ranges.interpretation: Severely disabling disease; still able to walk or stand unassisted but markedly incapacitated.

ranges.description: Confinement to bed or wheelchair unless aided
ranges.interpretation: Confinement to bed or wheelchair unless aided; complete invalidism.

references: Hoehn MM, Yahr MD. Parkinsonism: onset, progression and mortality. Neurology. 1967 May;17(5):427-42. doi: 10.1212/wnl.17.5.427.

Goetz CG, Poewe W, Rascol O, Sampaio C, Stebbins GT, Counsell C, Giladi N, Holloway RG, Moore CG, Wenning GK, Yahr MD, Seidl L; Movement Disorder Society Task Force on Rating Scales for Parkinson's Disease. Movement Disorder Society Task Force report on the Hoehn and Yahr staging scale: Status and recommendations. Mov Disord. 2004 Sep;19(9):1020-8. doi: 10.1002/mds.20213.

Shulman LM, Gruber-Baldini AL, Anderson KE, Fishman PS, Reich SG, Weiner WJ. The clinically important difference on the unified Parkinson's disease rating scale. Arch Neurol. 2010 Jan;67(1):64-70. doi: 10.1001/archneurol.2009.295.
formula: Clinical staging based on motor symptoms: Stage 1 (unilateral), 1.5 (unilateral + axial), 2 (bilateral, balance intact), 2.5 (bilateral, recovers on pull-test), 3 (bilateral, postural instability), 4 (severe disability, independent), 5 (wheelchair/bed-bound).
notes: Modified version adds intermediate stages 1.5 and 2.5 to original 1967 scale
Higher stages correlate with greater disability and reduced quality of life
Stages 1-3 considered minimally disabling, stages 4-5 severely disabling
Movement Disorder Society recommends using original 1-5 scale due to lack of validation of 0.5 increments
Primary focus on motor symptoms; does not assess non-motor features
Useful for tracking disease progression and clinical decision-making
Can guide decisions about medication adjustments, surgical interventions, and care planning
Does not capture cognitive decline, mood disorders, or other non-motor symptoms
Should be used alongside other assessment tools for comprehensive evaluation
Pull test: examiner stands behind patient and pulls backward on shoulders
